text:
It would really depend on the nature of the startup. Is it B2B or B2C? E-commerce? SaaS?

I always have a bent toward creating long-form pieces of content optimized for topics your audience is searching for, if it makes sense for your brand. It doesn't always. That's one way to grow email signups to build anticipation as launch time comes closer. 

It's going to take several months for content like that to get real traction on a brand new website, so why not start now?!

FWIW, it might make more sense in some cases to focus on PR first or strategize for social first. I'm just entrenched in SEO content, so that's my first response.

text: Give them a good bribe would be my answer. Why should someone fill out the survey? Try and make it worth their time

elements.text: Give them a good bribe would be my answer. Why should someone fill out the survey? Try and make it worth their time

text:
A lot of it is dependent on your go-to-market strategy and how you're looking to compete in the market.

But generally speaking - I would focus on the buying triggers of the current (or hypothesized) buying journey as closely as possible. And start with the content pieces that are closest to driving a sale.

text: Catching up on this thread now, <@U02PX7U46F9>. Super curious about your thoughts on quizzes (although all the video strategies are spot on!). I've been thinking about how to leverage quiz content in B2B, either in chatbot format or quiz platform. Have you done any experimentation?
